articles.title: Margot Robbie Praises Gavin & Stacey as a Top TV Comedy
articles.summary: Hollywood actress Margot Robbie has expressed strong admiration for the BBC sitcom Gavin & Stacey, calling it the best show ever. In an interview on the Table Manners podcast, she discussed her love for the comedy, which centers on family and friendship dynamics after two characters from different towns meet. Robbie highlighted the series finale, where Smithy proposes to Nessa, as particularly enjoyable, noting she watched it twice. She also shared her enthusiasm with entertainment legend Bette Midler during a dinner, leading to Midler starting to watch the show. The finale aired on Christmas Day 2024, attracting nearly 12 million live viewers and over 20 million total watches, making it a record-breaking event. Meanwhile, Robbie is promoting a new film adaptation of Wuthering Heights, but took time to praise the sitcom's impact. Additionally, the real-life house used as Uncle Bryn's home in Barry is now for sale, and Welsh comedian Rob Brydon sent Robbie a birthday message in character after learning she is a fan. The article shows how celebrity endorsements can boost a show's popularity and connect fans across generations.

articles.title: Pinnington Jones' Rise and Fall at the Dallas Open
articles.summary: Jack Pinnington Jones, a 22-year-old British tennis player, experienced a breakthrough week at the Dallas Open, showcasing his potential on the ATP Tour. He began by successfully navigating two rounds of qualifying to enter the main draw. In the tournament, he achieved a significant upset by defeating Flavio Cobolli, the world number 20, marking the biggest win of his career. He followed this with a victory over Eliot Spizzirri to advance to the quarter-finals. However, his dream run was halted by veteran Marin Cilic, the 2014 US Open champion, who won decisively in straight sets. Despite the loss, Pinnington Jones is set to rise 43 places in the ATP rankings, moving from 181st to 138th, reflecting his improved form. This performance comes after he opted to forgo his final year at Texas Christian University to pursue tennis professionally, following a strong run that included a final at a challenger event in Egypt. The article also highlights Victoria Mboko's success at the Qatar Open, where she defeated top players to reach the final, adding context to emerging talents in tennis.

articles.title: Catherine Zeta-Jones Explores Art Collecting and Its Connection to Her Film Role
articles.summary: Catherine Zeta-Jones, a well-known actor, has recently taken up art collecting as a personal hobby, which aligns with her latest film role in The Gallerist, where she portrays an art consultant. She owns works by notable artists such as sculptor Henry Moore and contemporary artist Marc Quinn, indicating her growing interest in the art world. Living in New York with her husband Michael Douglas, she notes that her social circle includes more art enthusiasts compared to Los Angeles, reflecting her immersion in the city's vibrant art scene. For their shared birthday, Douglas gifted her a piece by Marc Quinn, whose sculptures have sold for high prices, like Myth Venus. Zeta-Jones describes herself as an eclectic collector, frequently purchasing artworks from flea markets and during travels as mementos. This hobby contrasts with the darker themes of The Gallerist, a comedy-thriller about art fraud, highlighting how her real-life passion is more about appreciation and personal connection to art.

articles.title: Postponement of Eurovision 2026 Live Tour Amid Challenges
articles.summary: The European Broadcasting Union (EBU) has confirmed the postponement of the inaugural Eurovision Song Contest live tour for 2026. Originally scheduled to visit 10 European countries this summer, starting at London's O2 Arena on June 15, the tour has been shelved due to unforeseen circumstances. Martin Green, the contest's director, stated that despite efforts from the team, producers, and promoters, unresolved challenges led to this difficult decision. Ticket holders will receive full refunds, and the EBU plans to relaunch the tour later to ensure a world-class experience. The tour was intended as part of Eurovision's 70th birthday celebrations, featuring memorable past performers like Johnny Logan and Katrina, as well as current entrants. Meanwhile, the 2026 contest in Vienna proceeds as planned, but it faces boycotts from countries such as Iceland, Spain, and Ireland over issues like Israel's participation and voting fairness. In response, the EBU has tightened voting rules to reduce government influence, following member-approved reforms that allow Israel to remain.

articles.title: From Package Delivery to Movie Magic: A Belfast Animator's Journey
articles.summary: James Carson, a Belfast-born creative, has transformed his career from delivering packages for an animation company to becoming a CG Supervisor at Sony Pictures Imageworks, where he oversees 3D computer-generated elements for major films. His portfolio includes notable works like Mulan, Spider-man: Into the Spiderverse, and Alice Through the Looking Glass, but he gained significant recognition as a key contributor to KPop Demon Hunters, a Golden Globe-winning animated film that became a global sensation. Carson aims to inspire the next generation of animators, emphasizing that the industry has expanded with new companies and advancements in artificial intelligence, offering more opportunities than ever before. He started as a runner and advanced through roles, eventually moving to Canada for job prospects. Recently, he brought KPop Demon Hunters to Belfast for a special showing at RENDR, a festival exploring film, gaming, animation, and technology, which included behind-the-scenes insights and interactive activities. Carson's story highlights the evolving landscape of animation, where dedication and adaptability can lead to impactful careers in entertainment.

articles.title: Twisted 2D Magnets Form Skyrmions for Advanced Data Storage
articles.summary: Researchers have identified a novel magnetic state in a twisted two-dimensional material, chromium iodide, which consists of four atomic layers. By rotating two stacked bilayers of this material, they generated skyrmionsâ€”nanoscale magnetic structures that are topologically protected and highly stable. These skyrmions are among the smallest and most durable information carriers in magnetic systems, offering potential for ultra-dense data storage as global data volumes increase. The team used quantum sensing with nitrogen-vacancy centers in diamond to detect the extremely weak magnetic signals, overcoming measurement challenges. This discovery not only advances storage technology but also challenges existing magnetic theories, indicating that current models need refinement to explain electron behavior in atomically thin materials. The international collaboration involved scientists from multiple countries, with theoretical support from the University of Edinburgh, highlighting the importance of interdisciplinary research in quantum technologies.
